Significantly, the integration of wind turbines into power systems is hindered. To map global wind energy infrastructure, we develop deep learning models to automatically locate wind turbines in satellite imagery. Using only image-level supervision, we experiment with several weakly supervised convolutional neural networks to detect the presence and locations of wind turbines. Our best model, which we call DeepWind, achieves an average precision of 0.866 on the test set. DeepWind demonstrates the potential of automated approaches for identifying wind turbine locations using satellite imagery, ultimately assisting with the management and adoption of wind energy worldwide.

The decarbonization of the electricity sector and decreasing costs are accelerating the adoption of renewable energy, with 50% of the worldwide capacity expected to be renewable by 2035. Wind energy is growing rapidly, with 591 GW of capacity deployed by 2018—a 60% increase in 5 years—and a 130% increase expected by 2035. Knowing the location and type of installed wind turbines is critical for various stakeholders, including wind developers, electricity grid operators, utilities, city planners, and policymakers.

Currently, there are more than 398,000 wind turbines installed worldwide, but only 42% are mapped with accurate locations. An automated approach to localizing wind turbines would enable efficient identification of their locations and the construction of a more complete, up-to-date, global database of wind energy infrastructure. Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have demonstrated success in image-based localization tasks, including semantic segmentation and object detection. However, much of this success has been attributed to the use of fully supervised methods that require large datasets with detailed annotations, which can be expensive and time-consuming to collect.

To address this, we leverage advances in weakly supervised methods, which use image-level classification labels to localize objects without detailed annotation. These methods have emerged as an effective alternative to fully supervised counterparts, enabling advances in various fields, including healthcare and energy.

We develop DeepWind, a deep learning model to automatically localize wind turbines from satellite imagery. We use satellite images annotated with image-level binary classification labels from the U.S. Wind Turbine Database, a manually curated database containing more than 50,000 wind turbine locations in the U.S. Without bounding boxes for fully supervised localization models, we develop a variety of weakly supervised localization models to identify the locations of wind turbines in satellite imagery. We evaluate each model on turbine location prediction, and our best model, DeepWind, achieves an average precision of 0.866 on the test set.

The dataset used to develop the models contains 42,255 positive images and 58,672 negative images for a total of 100,927 images. We use latitude and longitude coordinates in the U.S. Wind Turbine Database (USWTDB) for the positives, excluding those with low location confidence or without corresponding imagery. We have two negative sets, one sampled randomly across the U.S. and the other containing visually similar objects to turbines with an open-source GeoVisual search tool. For all inputs, we obtain high-resolution satellite imagery of size 1500x1500. We split the dataset into training (97,825 images, 41,182 positives, 3,392 difficult negatives) and validation (1,427 images, 432 positives, 1,000 difficult negatives) sets.
